channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: American Woman Dies in Stabbing in Abu Dhabi
item.description: The 37-year-old woman and mother of 11-year-old twins was attacked by an unknown assailant in the bathroom of a shopping mall.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: U.S. Calls on Cuba to Free American Held Since 2009 as Spy
item.description: Relatives say Alan P. Gross, an American government contractor, is suicidal over a lack of progress in his case.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: ‘Superbugs’ Kill India’s Babies and Pose an Overseas Threat
item.description: Researchers say a significant share of the bacteria in India — in its water, sewage, animals, soil and even its mothers — are resistant to nearly all antibiotics.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother nursing her newborn at a hospital in Haryana, where almost every baby born in hospitals in recent years has been injected with antibiotics.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Both Attack ISIS, but Try Not to Look Like Allies
item.description: Tehran is showing a new willingness to conduct military operations openly on foreign battlefields rather than covertly and through proxies.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: British Regulator Urges Home Births Over Hospitals for Uncomplicated Pregnancies
item.description: Women with uncomplicated pregnancies are better off with midwives, as hospitalization increased the chances of surgical intervention and infection, guidelines suggested.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: Colombia and Rebels Agree to Talks
item.description: After the release of an army general captured by rebel fighters, the government of Colombia and the country’s largest guerrilla group said on Wednesday that they would soon resume peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Calenzano Journal: Amid Bugs, Hail, Floods and Bacteria, Italian Olives Take a Beating
item.description: The olive fruit fly and various weather problems helped make 2014 Italian olive oil’s annus horribilis.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federico Dufour among olive trees infected by fruit flies that ravaged his crop this year.

item.title: Number of Migrants Killed While Fleeing Soars
item.description: The International Organization for Migration said nearly 5,000 have died in journeys for a better life, a majority in the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Turkish Police to Get More Search Powers
item.description: A bill passed by the Turkish Parliament gives the police wider latitude to conduct searches and the government greater control over the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: World Briefing: Palestinian Teenager Accused of Stabbing 2 Israelis
item.description: Two Israeli men were wounded in an attack in a West Bank supermarket, and the suspect was shot and wounded by an off-duty guard who was shopping there.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil Plans Naval Mission in Africa
item.description: Plans for a mission in the island nation of São Tomé and Príncipe aim to foster defense cooperation.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: World Briefing: Swedish Government Collapses
item.description: A standoff over a budget plan in Parliament led to plans for new elections next year.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: World Briefing: Bombing in Yemen Targets Iranian Envoy’s Home
item.description: An attack on the Iranian ambassador’s residence in Sana, the Yemeni capital, killed at least three people.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Early-Childhood Separations, Common in China, Said to Hold Hidden Dangers
item.description: While the reasons for sending young children to boarding schools have changed in modern China, the emotional toll remains much the same, experts say.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: DePaul Catholic High School in Wayne, N.J., has recruited students from China.

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuelan Opposition Politician Charged in Plot to Kill President
item.description: The authorities charged the politician, María Corina Machado, with taking part in a plot to assassinate President Nicolás Maduro, but they did not make evidence public.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Shovels Untouched, Archaeologists Survey a Medieval Town in Britain
item.description: Researchers used highly sophisticated sensors to map Old Sarum, an 11th-century town near Stonehenge.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: A Gay Mayor in Poland? No Big Deal
item.description: The victory of a gay candidate amounts to a sea change in conservative Poland, where the Catholic Church wields enormous political power.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Sony Pictures and F.B.I. Widen Investigation Into ‘Sophisticated’ Cyberattack
item.description: The studio, working with law enforcement agencies, has been exploring whether the hacking was related to one of Sony’s coming movies, “The Interview.”
item.dc:creator: By BROOKS BARNES and NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: Sony headquarters in Culver City, Calif. Hackers crippled the movie studio’s computer systems.

item.title: Indian Official’s Firing Is Sought Over Remarks
item.description: Sadhvi Niranjan Jyoti, asked an audience “whether you want a government of those born of Ram, or those born illegitimately.” Ram is a Hindu god.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Brazil's Red-Scare Nostalgia
item.description: The right wing is trying its best to turn the president into a Communist.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA BARBARA
